Franklin Elementary School is one of two Tennessee schools selected as a 2019 National ESEA Distinguished School for the extraordinary success of their students. There are only 73 schools across the nation to receive this recognition by the ESEA Network, a membership organization made up of ESEA Program Administrators and their staff charged with managing their state federal education program from each of the states and territories.

Franklin Special School District Director of Schools, Dr. David Snowden, said that Franklin Elementary’s year-round approach to scrutinizing student data as they plan for instruction is a key to the school’s success. “The academic growth of all students is grounded in the focus and dedication by the teachers, staff members and leadership at Franklin Elementary. Their consistent use of student data to inform instructional decisions remains paramount in their work each day,” Snowden said.

Read more: https://fssd.org/esea-distinguished-schools/

shared_text:
Williamson Medical Center
December 3, 2019 at 5:20 PM ·

You’ve likely been hearing a lot about vaping in recent news. While the FDA and CDC are still investigating these lung injuries, the common link is that patients reported the use of e-cigarettes, or vaping products. This hit too close to home for two Williamson Medical Group pulmonologists.

After Drs. Devin Sherman and Tufik Assad personally treated patients at Williamson Medical with vaping illnesses, they knew they needed to get in front of the teens in our community. Both physicians have recently spoken about the dangers of vaping and tobacco products to Franklin Special School District and Williamson County Schools students, parents and staff.

A special thank you to the Williamson County Schools STARS counselors, Williamson County Health Department, Williamson County Anti-Drug Coalition and the Tennessee Department of Health for allowing us to work alongside of you to help educate the youth in our community.

This article highlights the reason our schools are being trained in the Tennessee Department of Education's pilot for trauma-informed schools. Trauma-informed practices help create a school environment that not only helps students but also supports and empowers teachers in their daily interactions with students. Research shows the benefits of implementing trauma-informed approaches in schools include improved school climate, decrease in suspensions and expulsions, improved attendance, and an improved teacher sense of satisfaction and safety. Liberty Elementary was one of the first schools selected to participate in this intensive training and teacher leaders have shared their professional learning across the district with other FSSD schools.

This designation indicates to the public that school staff is trained and prepared to respond to a cardiac emergency. The FSSD’s eight schools join 200 others with the Project ADAM Heart Safe Campus designation.
“We were committed to achieving this certification because the students, visitors and employees of every FSSD school now have a better chance of surviving a sudden cardiac arrest (SCA),” said Amy Fisher, RN, FSSD District Nurse.
Read more at https://fssd.org/all-fssd-schools-receive-project-adam-heart-safe-designation/

Congratulations Mrs. Grooms!

All applicants should bring Social Security cards, birth certificates for all household members, proof of income, picture ID of anyone in the household 18 or over. Applicants for the mainstream voucher program should also bring proof of disability.

The FSSD is happy to be the recipients of a state literacy Read to Be Ready grant, which is funding a four-week summer reading camp for 20 rising first- through third-grade students who will benefit from the review of literacy and reading skills. (https://www.tn.gov/readtobeready/why-read-to-be-ready-.html).

FSSD was awarded $23,800 to provide students with authentic experiences designed to develop their reading abilities, vocabulary, and love of reading. The classes are divided into 3 age groups with students from all over the district participating at Johnson Elementary School. Students and teachers work together for four hours each day for four weeks, each day increasing confidence and having fun with their peers. The grant provides each student with several books to keep at the end of camp, enabling them to continue to practice the skills they learn at camp with family members at home. The camp is directed by Franklin Elementary Reading Coach Niki Sidler and supervised by District Reading Supervisor Dr. Gina Looney.

Summer is an exciting time for children to enjoy time with friends and family, but for many children, summer can mean many hungry days. Just as learning does not end when school lets out, neither does a child’s need for good nutrition. For the ninth consecutive year, the Franklin Special School District is partnering with the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) to offer a Seamless Summer Food Service program (SSFS) to children. The SSFS helps to bridge the summer hunger gap by providing free breakfast and/or lunch to kids 18 and under at community sites during the months of May, June and July.

The 2018 Seamless Summer Food Service program kicks off Tuesday, May 29. The program’s goal is to significantly reduce child hunger over the summer months so there are no forms to fill out or qualifications to meet. Adults may purchase breakfast for $2.25 and lunch for $3.50.

Read more here: http://fssd.org/free-breakfast-lunch-summer-ensure-kids-dont-go-hungry-2/

post_text: We are happy to report that students in grades 3-8 successfully completed their first TNReady tests in English Language Arts this morning. Although many other districts have experienced significant problems in online testing, the Franklin Special School District opted to use paper and pencil tests this year. Based on the limited amount of online practice activities that were available from the state leading up to the testing period, our administrators and teachers felt that paper and pencil was a more reliable and familiar testing format. We have experienced no problems in our first day of testing. Testing in our district will resume next Thursday and will end May 2. Thank you to our parents for your part in assuring your children woke well-rested and ready for this morning’s test. We are confident the remaining testing days will be as smooth as today.
